questions.question: Close the windows. Let the windows ...................
questions.description: When we change an imperative sentence to passive voice, we use let with be + past participle.

questions.question: Feed the dogs. Let the dogs .....................
questions.description: When we change an imperative sentence to passive voice, we use let with be + past participle.

questions.question: Tell the truth. Let the truth .......................
questions.description: When we change an imperative sentence to passive voice, we use let with be + past participle.

questions.question: Has anybody answered your question? Has your question ...........................?
questions.description: The present perfect in the passive form becomes has/have + been + past participle.

questions.question: Do cats attack snakes? ................ snakes .................... by cats?
questions.description: In the simple present tense, the passive form is made with is/am/are + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: Did the noise frighten you? .............. you .................. by the noise?
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: When will they announce the results? / When will the results ......................?
questions.description: In the simple future, the passive form is made with will + be + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: Do foolish drivers cause accidents? ................... accidents ................... by foolish drivers?
questions.description: In the simple present tense, the passive form is made with is/am/are + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: They have spent a lot of money on the new house. / A lot of money ........................ on the new house.
questions.description: In the present perfect, the passive form is made with has/have + been + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: The cat is chasing the mouse. / The mouse ........................ by the cat.
questions.description: In the present continuous tense, the passive form is made with is/are/am + being + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: The Pied Piper's music attracted the rats of Hamelin. / The rats of Hamelin ....................... by the Pied Piper's music.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.
